speaker: Pat Toomey
date: stated on August 17, 2016 in an op-ed in the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.:
text: Pat Tommy has historically been one of the most pro-trade legislators in the Senate. The Republic of Pennsylvania -- now in a political battle of his life trying to keep his seat -- even wrote a book in 2009 called The Way to Prosperity, which harnessed the benefits of free trade. But last week, Tommy wrote a newspaper article that appeared in the post-Gazett Pittsburgh newspaper denouncing the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal led by the Obama administration, in which he wrote, "We should not go through a flawed deal just to finish the deal." "We must abandon the Trans-Pacific Partnership and return to the negotiating table to get an agreement that would create jobs and economic growth here at home." This position came from Tommy, and it was surprising, largely because last year the Senator voted in favour of the Trade Promotion Authority, which was largely described as a way for Washington to accelerate the path of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. So did Tommy reverse his position on the program, especially as the general support for the agreement faded? We do not judge the policy itself, but let us look at the facts of whether Tommy has changed his position or not. The Trans-Pacific Partnership will be one of the largest regional trade transactions in history. It includes the United States and 11 other countries - including Japan, Australia, Mexico and Singapore - on the edge of the Pacific Ocean, which accounts for one third of world trade, and the Obama administration has seen it as an effort to limit China ' s influence in the region. However, the agreement left both parties separate, with some considering that the effort would eliminate jobs in the United States and encourage foreign outsourcing. Her campaign indicated that in 2015, Tommy voted in favour of the Trade Promotion Authority, or the Trade Promotion Agency, which was known as the Fast Track Bill. That legislation was essentially a procedural vote in Congress that would facilitate the passage of a final trade deal because it required legislators to give a final trade deal a vote up or down without any amendments. The Obama Administration said that this was a crucial step in the negotiating process with other countries participating in the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The interview was described as involving the Radio and Television Corporation. But interviewer Joe Scarboro asked Tommy about the trade deal. While experts say that voting in favour of the Trade Promotion Authority legislation was not necessarily a symbolic vote of confidence in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the end result was that the Trans-Pacific Partnership would not have happened without it. In addition, in the past year, an interview was held with Tommy - who was largely pro-trade in the past - on MSNBC and supported a trade deal, not just a trade partnership agreement, which was a procedural vote in Congress. When Tommy was asked several times during the interview about the benefits of the trade transaction, he did not ease his feelings by saying that he would retain judgement on the Trans-Pacific Partnership until the negotiations were concluded. He's just saying now, while he's ready to re-election, that he wanted to wait to make a decision about whether he's supporting TPP or not. We evaluate this a full flop.
